Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Testing theories of mutualism in the context of rapid culture change

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Human societies everywhere deal with adverse social and environmental conditions that put livelihoods at risk, but they also tend to develop traditions and institutions that help adapt to those conditions. In the American Southwest, for example, droughts and floods can threaten cattle ranchers. In response, ranchers have developed a social institution, called "neighboring," in which ranchers help neighbors in need. What would happen to institutions like neighboring, however, when the economy changes quickly? Around the world, herding can be a high-risk livelihood, with herd sizes routinely prone to sudden fluctuations due to drought, disease, and, in some countries, raids. Herders routinely have similar stock friendships, or networks of cattle lending and sharing. Some researchers suggest that stock friendships might be an example of informal insurance systems to protect against cattle losses, whereas others claim that they might be useful for accumulating cattle wealth and political influence among households over time.

Aaron Lightner, under the supervision of Dr. Edward Hagen of Washington State University, investigates Maasai pastoralists in Tanzania, who have made their living by herding cattle for centuries. Recently, however, population growth, drought, and urbanization have forced many Maasai herders to turn to agriculture and cash economies, becoming less dependent on the high-risk business of herding cattle, a sudden, fundamental change to their local economy. This research will investigate how stock friendship institutions have adapted to the changing economy, collecting data on household-level income from cattle, agriculture, and other sources; partner preferences and reputations; past activity among stock friends; and social networks among stock friends. Social network analysis will help the researchers test existing ideas about how and why people are participating in stock friendships, and to understand how these reasons might vary among people who are highly impacted vs. less impacted by economic and environmental changes at the field site. This research provides a unique opportunity to investigate not only how stock friendships buffer economic risks, but also how stock friendships are adapting to changes that are affecting herders around the world.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project resulted in the successful completion of field research by Aaron Lightner among Tanzanian Maasai pastoralists in Monduli. This fieldwork, along with the travel and research permits required to do so, was supported by the NSF Doctoral Dissertation Improvement Grant, and will contribute to improving his dissertation project. During the funding period, Lightner made necessary preparations to successfully and legally enter Tanzania and conduct fieldwork, and to complete a research trip for a length of about three months. The field research did, unfortunately, end earlier than anticipated due to the coronavirus pandemic.

While conducting fieldwork, Lightner was nevertheless able to engage in participant observation, key informant interviews, and semi-structured interviews and focus groups among several Maasai locals. Further, he personally collected comprehensive structured interviews from sixty locals, and recruited two local research assistants to help collect additional structured interviews during his stay. The data that was collected ended up expanding in scope to include questions about trust, science, and religion, because it became increasingly apparent that these aspects of the traditional institution that Lightner originally sought to study were highly relevant to his research questions. This field research also helped increase rapport with locals at the fieldsite, and to help improve the infrastructure of a local school, which was a project that local assistants requested aid with and were very glad to see completed.

The data resulting from this field research will contribute to the completion of Lightner's dissertation project, with an anticipated completion date of summer 2021. It has also allowed him to write multiple academic articles that are currently in preparation, including a social network analysis, two experimental studies, and a quantitative cultural study. So far, one paper, testing different theories about trust and social learning, is currently submitted for review after a previous round of revisions. The dissertation that Lightner is currently completing will not only clarify existing theories about cooperation and sharing behaviors, but also about trust, science, and religion in the face of a rapidly changing culture and economy.
